name: q16_3
probTex:
Suppose that the radius of convergence of
\[f(z)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_nz^n\]
is R. Prove the power series
\[\sum_{n=0}^\infty rac{1}{n+1}a_nz^{n+1}\]
has the same radius of convergence $R$, and is actually the derivative of $f$.
solnTex:
Recall the radius of convergence $R$ is given by the root test,
\[ rac{1}{R}=\limsup_{n	o\infty}\sqrt[n]{a_n}.\]
To show the new radius is the same, we have to show
\[\limsup_{n	o\infty}\sqrt[n]{a_n}=\limsup_{n	o\infty}\sqrt[n]{ rac{a_n}{n+1}}.\]
However, we know $\limsup\sqrt[n]{a_n}= rac{1}{R}$. Then all we have to show is that $\limsup\sqrt[n]{n+1}=1$. This is easy enough,
\[\lim\sqrt[n]{n+1}=\lim e^{ rac{\ln(n+1)}{n}}=\exp\left(\lim rac{\ln(n+1)}{n}ight)=\exp\left(\lim rac{ rac{1}{n+1}}{1}ight)=e^0=1.\]
So we have shown that the radius of convergence is the same. Moreover, let $S_n$ be the $n^{th}$ partial sum for $f$. The derivative of $S_n$ is the $n+1^{th}$ partial sum of the series in question, call it $S'_n$. Because our convergence is uniform (on compact sets), we can swap limits around. Then
\[f'(z_0)=\lim_{z	o z_0} rac{f(z)-f(z_0)}{z-z_0}=\lim_{z	o z_0}\lim_{n	o\infty} rac{S_n(z)-S_n(z_0)}{z-z_0}=\lim_{n	o\infty}\lim_{z	o z_0} rac{S_n(z)-S_n(z_0)}{z-z_0}=\lim_{n	o\infty}S'_n(z_0).\]
